subject: Re: How to Spell...?
msgSnippet: ... curious ... (ex. It ) ... we ... (ex. ... otherwise). ... Money is spelled with letter #26 (because that s the way many non- North Americans pronounce
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "steveb_667"
<sbartok1632@e...> wrote:
> While I can think of no word offhand that would use this, I am
curious
> as to how to spell any word that would end with a "short I"
(ex. "It")
> sound? If we are to follow the Quikscript manual, it tells us that
we
> use letter #26 ("it") for when terminals that end with a "long E"
(ex.
> "monEY") are unstressed & letter #27 ("eat") when the terminal is
> stressed (ex. "legatEE").
>
> Also, the Quikscript manual does not clarify what to do for single
> syllable words that end with a "long E" sound (stressed or
otherwise).
> Should all one-syllable words that end in a "long E" sound end with
> letter #26 or letter #27?

"Money" is spelled with letter #26 (because that's the way many non-
North Americans pronounce it) and the name "Marie" would be spelled
with letter #27 because the sound is stressed and all the major
dialects say this vowel as a "long E" sound.

For single-syllable words that don't have abbreviations, one should
assume that the single syllable carries the stress of the word, and
it should be written it its fully enunciated form, so single-
syllable words ending in a "long E" sound like "free", "key"
and "tea" are spelled with letter #27.
